title: Watchmen star Regina King reveals how Sister Night costume left her wounded
text:
Regina King discusses costumes, comic lore, and cast chemistry in Watchmen (Picture: HBO)

Watchmen might have heeded Edna Mode’s ‘No capes’ warning from The Incredibles. The eccentric costume designer and scientist, however, might want to revise that stance to add ‘and skirts’ into the equation.

It’s a suggestion that Regina King would certainly offer to Mode if she could. Watchmen’s lead star, who plays Detective Angela Abar and vigilante alter-ego Sister Night, had her costume’s skirt to thank for her share of bumps and scrapes during filming. It’s all part of the job, King insisted to Metro.co.uk, and comes with the territory of taking part in the show’s acrobatic, brutal fight scenes.

‘I took a lot of spills in that skirt – you get wrapped up in it and you’d go down! – but I’m happy to say no broken bones,’ King revealed. ‘Just a few cuts and bruises. You know, the usual battle scars. Our stunt coordinator, who I worked with on The Leftovers, was very much aware of my ability. I also have an amazing stunt double – she’s a gymnast – and the combination of our abilities allowed them to choreograph the scenes so it could be a seamless sequence between the two of us.’

Regina King stars as Sister Night in Watchmen (Picture: HBO)

Set in the present day, but in an alternate reality to our own, Watchmen picks up 34 years after the legendary comic book series. Like the source material, vigilantes are part of this reality’s furniture and hide their identities with homemade costumes. Sister Night’s outfit is one of the show’s more elaborate ensembles, and King was unequivocal about how she felt when decked out in the nun-inspired get up.

‘It was powerful,’ she stated. ‘When I put the costume on, I think my body language does change. I just naturally fell into this stride that is clearly different from Angela. I would liken it to what American football players feel when they put on their uniform. There is something about their body language that changes. The first time I was able to be on a football field with NFL players, they’re like Transformers – they look and move like them and I thought, “Wow, look at these warriors.” I had that feeling when putting the costume on.’

King, who previously worked with showrunner Damon Lindelof on The Leftovers, had no connection to the world of Watchmen prior to being handed the pilot’s script. Even so, the positive experience of collaborating with Lindelof, coupled with the show’s unexpected opening sequence, ensured that she had no reservations about stepping into Angela’s and Sister Night’s shoes.

‘I had not read the graphic novel or seen the movie, so I had no connection to anything,’ King told us. ‘My connection was to Damon, and I absolutely loved that experience and his style of running a show and style of writing. He just had me at saying “This is what I’m doing next.” He delivered the script for me to read and I was blown away by the first five pages. I was like “Whoa, Tulsa Massacre – that’s what we’re doing? Okay, alright.”’

The Tulsa race riots, described as the single worst incident of racial violence in US history, resulted in the deaths of hundreds of black Oklahoma residents in 1921. The harrowing event, which took place in the Greenwood district known as ‘Black Wall Street’, makes for shocking viewing as an entry point for the show. King, though, draws parallels between the TV series and the comics in addressing some of the most pressing issues of their times in race and nuclear destruction respectively.

The Tulsa riots are described as the worst incident of racial violence in US history

(Picture: Everett/REX)

‘I had to take a pause, because it’s a story that I’ve always felt should be told,’ King explained. ‘I feel like so often, when we’re telling the stories of black people in America, it’s always a slave story. There are so many other stories that exist and that is one that my sister and I have always talked about.

‘I thought that it was fantastic that Damon was able to use the source material and follow the blueprint, which they did in the original, by finding something present day that has that looming threat over a country. He felt deep inside that this was the only entry point to a story that I could tell. That’s a very hard thing to do, I think, especially dealing with subject matter that’s so sensitive and that has a history that’s wrapped up in a lot of pain, anger, shame, and guilt.’

Advertisement

Watchmen’s difficult and serious subject matter may have some wondering if filming the series wasn’t fun. For King, that couldn’t be further from the truth. The Oscar and Emmy winner revealed that the cast’s familiarity with each other’s work made it feel like they knew one another before production began – a factor that helped with her intimate scenes with Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, who plays Angela’s husband Calvin.

Regina’s familiarity with Yahya Abdul-Mateen II helped with intimate Watchmen scenes (Picture: HBO)

‘You come to set with such a tremendous respect for everyone in their art form,’ King went on. ‘And then it turns out that everyone happens to be really cool, smart, interesting people on top of that.

‘You know, not to sound like, “We all got along” but we did. Yahya and I have such great chemistry. We met each other for the first time when we auditioned but then we didn’t see each other again until we had to act together. The first time we did was that love scene, so you hope that you have chemistry because that is so uncomfortable! There’s nothing sexy about it. You are truly acting and I felt so safe with him – and him with me – and we were both like “Alright, we’re about to do this” so we protected each other throughout.’

Watchmen’s iconic status means that there’s always apprehension when discussions about adapting it emerge. Coupled with creator Alan Moore’s well-publicised contempt for other works based on the series, and Lindelof’s worry at doing justice to the source material, and it’s perhaps puzzling why Lost’s co-creator would invite such pressure on himself. After all, Lindelof remains a die hard fan of the comics and cites the graphic novel as the chief influence behind his writing style.

Advertisement

With the show’s first two episodes being positively received overall by fans and critics alike, King is hopeful that the rest of the series will show how much adulation Lindelof holds for the source material and even entice some viewers to seek out the comics for themselves.

‘For Damon, I hope that, if there’s a spike in sales of the graphic novel, then that will probably be the biggest joy for him,’ King said. ‘That would show that we were successful, and pay homage to a piece of work and art that impacted Damon’s life in such a huge way.’

Watchmen continues this Sunday on HBO and follows a day later on Sky Atlantic. Episodes one and two are available to stream on NOW TV.
